awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C Spontaneously Synthesized RNA Protocells for Biological Catalysis
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
NASA defined life as "a self-sustaining chemical system capable of Darwinian evolution." Ribonucleic acid (RNA) plays a central role in carrying genetic information, translating protein, and regulating other functions. RNA is also hypothesized as one of the central molecules for prebiotic life as it is capable of self-replicating, self-cleaving, and catalyzing other biological reactions in the absence of macromolecular biological catalysts such as enzymes. However, the understanding of a plausible mechanism for the formation of RNA and ribozyme, an enzymatic form of RNAs, is still challenging. Previously, we have shown that RNA nucleosides, a purine or pyrimidine bases linked to a sugar, can be spontaneously formed from simple precursors, including D-ribose, nucleobase, and phosphoric acid in water microdroplets surround by the air at room temperature. This finding provides a new foundation for how RNA molecules can be formed without any biological energy source, biological enzymes, or natural catalyst such as minerals from precursor molecules that are not specially designed and synthesized. It also suggests that a protocell, a self-organized collection of biochemical compartments that can perform a minimal biological functions toward the origin of life, can be formed in microdroplets. However, a question may arise that this prebiotic RNA synthesis can be carried out only in water microdroplets surrounded by the air. This question is related to hypotheses suggesting that the early life form may have begun from bubbles in the hydrothermal vent or emulsions formed from oil-water mixtures. It is also questionable that the abiotic RNA synthesis can be done in lipid vesicles that have a different interface to water microdroplets or water-in-oil emulsions. In this project, we addressed whether RNA nucleosides can be spontaneously formed from simple precursors, including D-ribose, nucleobase, and phosphoric acid with magnesium ion (Mg2+), using three different prebiotic synthesis platforms, including (1) microemulsions, (2) liposomes, and (3) micro/nano-bubbles (Figure 1). Purine and pyrimidine ribonucleosides such as adenosine, cytidine, inosine, and uridine were successfully synthesized in those platforms that have different interfaces, including water-air, water-oil, and water-phospholipid. These findings suggest that the unique property of aqueous microdroplets, which enables thermodynamically unfavorable reactions to occur at room temperature, is universal as far as hydrophobic and hydrophilic interfaces are maintained. Our findings in this project suggest a plausible pathway for elucidating a possible missing link as to how the RNA world came about. 


Last Modified: 06/03/2021
Modified by: Richard N Zare

Image
  • Figure 1. Schematic of abiotic spontaneous formations of nucleosides including uridine, adenosine, cytidine, and inosine from D-ribose, and phosphoric acid in three different synthesis platforms including microemulsions, liposomes, and microbubbles.
    Richard Zare
    Public Domain
    Richard N Zare
    Figure 1
